titleStmt.title: CW 89
titleStmt.author: Carmichael, Alexander Archibald (1832‐1912)
titleStmt.sponsor: Edinburgh University Library and the Department of Scottish and Celtic Studies

interpretation.p: All digital surrogates of the original source are linked with the markup textfile.
All Gaelic (and English) texts have an English summary, index terms, keywords, and, where applicable, a taxonomic reference.
For some Gaelic (and English) texts a bibliographic reference(s) will be provided to other sources.

correction.p: Errors from the original source transcription have been kept to a minimum by employing stringent quality control procedures. In addition, all texts have been proof‐read by the text editors.

A guiding principle of the Alexander Carmichael notebooks markup procedure is to approximate the original document as closely as possible, so that the character of Carmichael's transcriptions is preserved along with its content. XML (eXtensible Markup Language), with its capacity to convey emendations such as deletions (crossed out) and supralinear additions and so forth, can digitally reproduce an authentic version which reflects the source documents.
Where authorial changes, e.g. substitution, have occurred in the text then this has been annotated.
Where there are errors they have been corrected and words which were difficulty to decipher has been indicated

In such cases missing words or letters have been supplied. Quotation marks and other missing grammatical marks have in the main not been supplied. Where there are gaps in the text usually because the word was inaudible (some background noise, perhaps) or where the transcriber could not make out what was being said in the act of transcription (perhaps the speaker was inarticulate or mumbling or for whatever reason) then these have been tagged, though not explained; where a word is now difficult, illegible or just unclear, then this has also been tagged.
All such changes have been annotated in accordance with TEI 5 procedures.

normalization.p: No normalization of the words such as changing the source text to conform with current Gaelic orthographic conventions has been undertaken. The texts are as given with only minor editorial changes. in order to preserve the integrity of the original texts.

quotation.p: All opening quotation marks, hyphens, dashes, apostrophes, periods, colons, etc. have been retained in the source text and have been encoded in accodance with ISO entity references, etc.
All double marks have been processed using straight quotation marks, that is, ". All single quotation marks have been rendered using apostrophe.

hyphenation.p: End‐of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.of‐line hyphenation has been retained. All unambiguous end‐of‐line hyphens have been retained, and the trailing part of a word has not been joined to the preceding line.

segmentation.p: Folio numbers have been added in pencil at the top of each notebook page are retained using the pb (pagebreak) element together with the n attribute for the page number and the ed attribute to specify the edition.
When an tale‐text or song which, more often than not, fills more than one page, it is segmented with page break.

langUsage.language: Approximately 40% of the fieldnote and transcription bokos are Scottish Gaelic, and the remaining 60% consist of English or Scots, along with stray quotations in Latin.

change.item: Added new Encoding and Profile Descriptions

div.p:
MsMiss Major Macleod, "Major Ann"
Flora Macdonald's daughter
She took the stocking off her foot
put a bit of peat in & went
to the door step & poundpounded
away saying as she did –

lg.l: Thig nighnighean Imhair as an tóll
Ach cha bhoin mise do ninnighean IImhair

div.p:
Dun-sgĕig, Calmonell, Kin
tire.

div.title: Iain Og Ile.
div.p:
Left EdinrEdinburgh on 31 JuMay
1887. & Glasgow 1 June for
Greenock to Tarbet Port Ellen
and Bridgend Islay. Marquis
of Lorne found steamer
at GreenokGreenock CaptCaptain Campbell
Airdpatrick at Airdpatrick
of West of West Tabert. In-
troduced to Lord Lorne at
his request. Found him on
the journey & hotel most
pleasant & friendly. On
parting this morning said
that he had been greatly
pleased to meet me. He
& CaptCaptain Campbell rtreturned
left this morning 3 June -
for Port Ellen

The inaugaration of the
monument to Iain Og Ile
went off yesterday most
splendidly. Great concourses
of people. Fine dinner hand
somely done and good speaking
afterwards except by myself.
Mine – Celtic Literature – was a bungled affair. I
coupled with it the name of
Mr Hector Maclean who
gave a learned discourse
Lord Lornes speechs good; CaptCaptain
Campbell's speech – reply to Army
& Navy – good & others.

Bridgend charming place
Islay house large building
charming grounds but some
what low-lying. Place wild
& flowers advanced far beyond
those round Edinburgh.

Thomas Hill gard.gardner his grand
father was butler his grandmother
a ladysmaid with MsMiss Campbell

4.5. 87
Catheag C bheag nan cud
ainean – red feet takstakes its food
from sea. Bridean – old
people say he takstakes his food fr.from
the sea – with his bill. He watches
the barr & when the seas comscomes up
to his bill opens up & he gobbles them
Thug an fhaoilean an spog
shamh bhon bhrid bha i dol
gu banis da ian uile agus
gun tiltill i Dihaoine –
Fhuair i sin agus thaingthainig
DhaoineDihaoine ach cha tug an
fhaoilfhaoileann an spog shnamh
da fhag bho DhaoineDhihaoine gu
DhaoineDihaoine

ThanChan eil aig a bhrid ach
glig glig not got back
his spog slislightly yelyellow
Loinean size of Druidean
starling shore bird not
or-ghlas – birds on sgualar
ach mhin-chlach gheal
sometimes up in fields thothough
sgarbh (30 miles from light.lighthouse
of PPort na haven to Innisour
lightlighthouse hel. An Truideag No
dog will eat the bone of the
truidetruideag thog thothough it will other bones
of same type of bird – will eat
bones of Lon smior &c Not
put its nose to it hardly –

The truideag said some
to the phr prophet of old
& the proprophet gave it thsthis as
a gift – no creatcreature will
injure its bone. In early
times.

The Irish army & thetheir
enemies were at war. The
eng.english were asleep & the Irish
were comgcoming upon them at
night. The Dreolan came
& began eageating the spriu'anspriuanan
on crumbs on the drum head
& waked the drummer who
beat to arms as the eng Irish
went past falg,falling upon their
guns since then the Irish
take a day in the year to kill
the Dreathan (wren) (St PatPatrick?)

Donald Macmhuirach
three score of timstimes had dogs call
the Druid.Duideag with diffdiiferent dogs this.

Glaistean tragh shore bird does
not eat st land food – all
sea food or shore -

Stearneal – comes oicheoidhche
BhealBhealltain - for ceartceartas if night
be stormy frfrom west he comes
not till folfollowing day. On nights
of great fog this w he was heard
coming across the hill from the
N.North E.East His voice heard makigmaking
his way throthrough fog at night. Leaves
end of sum.summer abutabout Lunasatadh
– The old take young out to sea
for milsmiles & comgcoming back – traingtraining
them tofor long flights. Then they
leave at – they go out to sea
betbetween thsthis & IrelIreland –

Fara-chrodhaichean [supralinear: = = Crotach-Bheag smalsmall
the old Crotach-mhor. They
come abtabout BealBealtainn & stay a month
Do not breed. They go to warmwarmer
climates – The Crotach mor
breed in the moor in Inistra
Nil. Some few 4 or 5, 6
comes for a day or so.

Drollan all the euns
in the ealtealtainn. The bird went
high. Had hold of the tail feathfeather
of the eagle. When she boastboasted
she was highhigher she flew out
from the sheltshelter of her tail & cridcried
out I am high. 12 eggs.

(Peatraig 21 eggs). Moss &
Rough & fine moss nest.
Of D-Drollan – door on side & as rondround
as caornag – caornag cells
of bees. The ealtealtainn is the almalarm
of the fishmenfishermen. The fishfishermen were
out to fish on oitir na
h-airde ear. They saw sgarts
Lab.laboriously tearing out sticks & straffs
of their nests down near sea
& build them up 50 ftfeet high
carrycarrying the young & eggs
by necks & eggs.

The fish-fishermen went there closely
& preppropelled accrdaccordingly. In four
days a ter.terrible storm came
& washed the face of the
rocks where nests had been.
The sgarts not on nest stradstranded
out at sea.

If gale comes frfrom N.North the Brid
leavsleaves north shore & goes to S.South shore
days] ere storm comes & leaves

Reamhag = Skylark. A
ciel Ni suas cho aird ri
no ian san ialt an chan
eil soisneacsoisneachd innte.

Ian-bollach a ghortghoirt – mid-
sum.summer makes neastnest in corn
- latest bird in ealtealtainn is takgtaking
out its allal. At ftfoot of fonan
neat near lowlowest branch
stansstands on top of fon.fonan not
so reamhag.

An glaisean = moss
chirper. Gaoisire & fiar
caoirichte geal.

Clachanan-fead do nal
cadalaich – Thug e mach
lalatha fhillfheill PPatrikck. Nest in beds
of moss – 5 white eggs. Goes
in to sleep in SeptSeptember & comecomes out
in March. St PPatrick. Has been
found in PPort na haven in turf
dyksdykes asleep in wintwinter with
two or three ribeagan fiar
geal na bheul. across to
keep his bill open to breathbreathe
Like polar bear with
his paw in his mouth -.

Old men truthful
got the bird so asleep

SeacainSeachdainn a ghamhna
bhocbhochd romhroimh 'Ill Phadruig ann
mum paisg a chailchailleach a seac.
anseachdainn – bha am feur a tinntighinn
gun taingtainig dhi nan
nach b urra di chumchumail
sios. Sear.Searrach a gharran
dian duinn. 3 lalatha thoirt
na h-eirbail as na hoighich.
They had so little to do out that
they divot this to the taking
out the tails. 3 lalatha fead ga tuar gheur fhuar –

She comes frfrom the hill – DonDonald
saw her come to the shore this
year in hot days. The
Amhsan Holland goose
GiGiadh amhamhsan t Olland each
comes betbetween sea weed on sea
before storm. 3 lalatha gobaig

An Luairegan breid
on sea in An glaic a sgò
– Not on shore. Smeorach
whins breed or tree le burach
cuid – na makes it water
tight – Ian buibuidh an t seacseacaid
yellow yet durgduring
Dir Di-diora di deoid "says
smeorsmeorach

sil romh tholl long na
lion na smior

div.p:
Cathag gob dearg & da
chasdearg – few about
shore here Cathag "Mēag" voice

Dreadful storm came & kilkilled
nearynearly all birds here – 10 or 11 yeryears
– the cats gave up eatgeating them
the dead bodisbodies strewn thruthrougout
places strand – they came to the houses
– loves especially – wood-
cocks ealtealtainn beag 10 or 20 birds
ealtealtainn mor 60 or 80 birds.
Nota 3 now of birds. Killed
the conas whins here. High
dyksdykes 4, 5 & 6 ftfeet high.

lubag, an, twisted yarns
off the crois

DonaldDonald's's grandfather, Fear
Bhollsa na h-Uaimh Moire,
had an airiairidh for his milk then
& knew something wrong with
the milk. Watched & saw a
serpent's trail. Saw serpent
on coiled on hillock
in cuaich shamhraishamhraidh
she had a toll geamh.geamhraidh
in gaoidh in
mar toll coin mor.
When she heard some
noise she raised her head
he fundfound two bullets in gun
& killed her. They never
saw a tingthing so big as this
was 9 ftfeet long. ShepShepherds killkilled
there on farms. Ceallrea
(Duncan cf) 7 score last
& 9 score year before. Each
farm on an average killkills
100 each year

LaLatha fheil BriBride thig nibhir
as an toll
Cha bhoin mi fhein do nibhir

div.p:
Bru deargan. Not seen in
summer till autautumn. Never
saw in its nest. l? His datdaughter got
one in hedge last year. Small
breac Hing hing a dall"
Drig drig "hingadall"

Clacharan coille dark
& moves close to ground. LiaLiath[th]
eggs. Clacharan coille light
red in colcolour. Same colcolour of eggs
Lintachain – small birds eggs
like fine thread black whole
lines around eggs. Moss fiar
& lines in hair.

Fulta-flier came here 10 or 12
yeasyears ago breatbreast fair yeallowyellow
back dark dun Irish sea
full of them at night

PartrigePatridge Can quite run
the peoplpeople of Reachlain Iris =

SpeargSpearag.Tha triuir ann
air nach eagal am beatha
tha eagal am beathbeatha
An SpearSpearag An t-Seabh.t-Seabhag
ruaruadh agus an t-Seabhag
ghorm. These fear
not any bird in the ealtealtainn
of these their killgkilling sights
The SpeargSpearag glassglas not
an Seabhag for from
its gne will not touch it
the SpeargSpearag will not kill
any birds larger than this
truideag but any other
than this she ki mang.manage
The seabh-ruaseabhag-ruadh will kill
as small as the truideag
if hungry but larger
as a rule always workgworking
at Peatraigean – The
seabh-ghormseabhag-ghorm will kill
any in the ealtealtainn at one
blow except the eagle –
if it gesgets chance will comcome
down on eagle but the eagle
while upside down & get
witwith its claws. ThereforTherefore does
not come near it – would
pierce it throthrough were it not
the fear of the turn up – with
one stroke of its bumbeum na sgesgiath
will kill partpartridge geageadh glas

John Maconail WWest Eilester
saw at EilesEilester saw the blue
hawk aftafter ealtealtainn of rock
pigpigeons they flew up she fol.followed
& struck on which hurlhurled
down near the man he pickpicked
it up. The pigpigeons flew high
& she went up again
struck anothanother which this
man pick up she went
up struck anothanother & it fell
She then went up & came
down with tremdtermendous swirl
making straight upon him
he jerked a little aside
she struck the road driving
her bill hard down & flat
its body when its entrails
gushed out flat. The
cal.calman kept in own clump
from fear.

A man at PPort na haven
could see an ugsa breaking
a mile – He saw the gull
could see the ugsa breakgbreaking
3 miles off

Feadag mhoine nest
in coincoinneach[neach] bhan & puts coincoinneach
bhan over eggs.

Ball Balair. bothan largelarger
than sgait – White spot on
thigh.

lg.l:
Sin a dh ol mi fhein s mo
sheanmhair

Deoch do dh ian balair
bothain –

Hora mhoilean
(cu) s tu gun snodlain

div.p:
Beiste donna = otters
killed an otter larger than
a barn door. TheTheyneat larger
than any are seen in Islay
(twice attacked)

An croman fion. croman
ruaruadh Corr ghrieachghritheach. Never
got nest. Nest f in cuile in
lon gus an corr us crotach
best chance of crotach dry
bird high & hail &
StriksStrikes the eye of crotach
Geadh corr is crotach

DonDonald sneakdsneaked behibehind dyke
to see how near he could
get to geese in a pool
– tame geese. One stood
on a knoll & said make
one for those in pool
came up & struck seven
or 8 or nine flaps in the
face & then went back to
pool – The chastised goose
roared out for long aftafterwards
Never attempattempted to move.
Geese go to Loch dearg in
Ire.Ireland from this.
Callaidh = tame

Da-ri-tre = CornCorncrake
Buna-bhuilBuna-bhuachaill – G.Great NNorth DivDiver

Saw ravens killgkilling hens here
Gulls killgkilling ducklings

Serpent casts ncochal na
narach abtabout Lunastadh.
Som Then serptserpent strings
the col.colour of its breac-buibreac-buidh a
he orders comes on skins
of perperson Young cocks cut
length wise appapplied to wndwound
fresh brioskaineach og
oin – not wholly dead
A man here lately saw a
serpt he threatthreatened it. it jumpjumped
up 12 ftfeet in the air near
him. When it fell he kilkilled it
They come togethtogether in –
& copulate – All the belly
scalsscales are used in traveltravelling
They will chase childchildren
but not adults – Donald studied
them move & never knew
how they camcame togtogether till he
watched closeyclosely.

Corr ghirghritheach bhreaoc. Gold
throat in winter snow –
glittering – all the rest brioc
blue. CailCailleach oicheoidhche bheag
sa CCailleach oidhche mhor.

Studied the easgan & the
torranan from fly depost eggs
DonDonald 51 yrsyears of age

A Tharaint. – an uraidh –
year before last. He tried
hair of horse or cow (rioba)
must be hole in head of hair
eel. Conachag = shell
Bailemeanach DonDonald lives in

An cleireach mac crubag
Dearc luachrach lotailotaidh
nan sin 3 siuil mhara
18 horhours. His sister was stung
& it lastlasted thus.

Calmoir
Herring haig – DifDifficult to fish.

Donnag an among stones
in shore. Gearran cnu cnuac-
ach 3½ ininches in Gearran greis-
4 or 5 brog 4 or 5½ ininches

Asgail = oxter. Bradan
LeanLeathann = HalHalibut

Man fishfished at Oin Haili
geo on Locha Gruinneard
Isla CCalum cillcille came gave
me a fish – got
a losgain the found him
AoiAghaidh gach iasg a mach
& gun ghin idir a thila
asthilleas. Since then all the
sal.salmon face out to the sea & not
come up the lake to cladh.
Before then the lake was
full of salmon.

Glasag back dark blue
in shell Gīmhseag thin
but as paper

A woman was sheailing
in Colosey Left her child rolled
in a blanket near where she
was when an eagle swept
down & cariedcarried it off. The
eagle cariedcarried it to Islay & let
it down on a hillock near
which DonDonald's grandfather hid
himself when he saw her coming
the child screamed.

Feuch rist e! rist e!
Sguab as e! Sguab as e!
Goaran = Gobha Athar

Airdbheala Port Bheala or
yeala WWest of PtPort na haven Isla
Cala

Kilchoman three crosses and
a criminal going between
these was safe

Inverawe Sneeze – Com
mon to this famiyfamily – in some
more developed –

An old laydylady of this was reading
prayer for the household
With it came on. She stopped
& said to herself – "Deil take the Inv
aweInverawe sneeze" Ms Carmichael
(Rev Donald) could hardly
go on with the prayer – then
book being given to her.

Donald Macunchy said
yesterday Sunday there
wldwould be a slight rain to
day – a small shower
from the manner in which
the clouds formed. Yes
terday Sunday was a bright
beautiful mild day as
unlike rain as could be
6 June 1887 Rained midday Claidville Islay Monday

Landed at P.Port Ellen
Wednesay 1 June drove
to Bridgend. 2 triangles
of moor. Friday came
with Helen Carmichael
my sister in law & her niece
Annie Macphaidean
home to Claidville

Cilleluaran 6.6.87
Stone 5 x 3½

div.p:
Same Gaelic in Glens IrelIreland
they have in Arasaig from
which 33 boats. In Innis
Ōin from Islay from TraiTraigh
Ghrunnard Islay – namynamely
Macaulays. Colin
Mac Dhonacha ((Camp.Campbell (Mor)
of Eiles Aoileisteadh
3 2 boatloads frfrom sunrise to
sundown.

Callag bheag
nan cudainean Sea –
swallow.

Trosg (Bodach ruaruadh son of Trosg)
ugsa Card smallag Pioc
ach beag P'iocacPiocach mor
usg ugsa. Donnag Laing
og Liuag Liu Carbh
anach Brager 2 spots
like had.haddock or S.St P.Peter's fish.
5 fins on S.St P.Peter'sfish SamSame
shape. Siolag grows
large as a piocach.
Grow larger in Cul-dav
och Inis Oīn. The
big in centre of stream &
smaller by degrees on side
Pean thuill with three
Four kinds of ling. Man
ach has larger iteach than
on ling – broader. Fionnag =
Whiting Donnag Ain
at Crudan

The gobag mhurlach agus
an Sgat breed same as
the cu like the dogs
Biorach in pouches
Casach = Snod iasgach
The gobag cuts this like
razor. DunDuncan saw
the eels breed from horse
hair – the two ends
alive – Rioba gaoiseid
boine does as well as horse hair

Bana Cathrathain. Sūcker
little small eel sucks blood
out of otherothers.

Gearran
cnuachach = narrow tail
large wide mouth some
as large as trosg

Creagag
(Rockfish) Pike sàl muc
creige They had them in
Barra they plaitplaited them
in sugan connlaich they
twist the end with this sugan
along the saobhan in the river
rising in Loch re neathach
Bacach = Turbot Bradan
Leathan = Halibut.

The Ugsa
& PiocPiocach are the cleanest eatseaters
in the sea. Fry of herring eat
cruban used as bait.

Blad-fo-lic = Sole fish
Leabag like fish of lobster
& red like this. 3 kinds of
leabag. Garbhag not so
good a fish as the liabag
Liabag – Roinneach
nan each large coarse
mackmackerel. Creanananch
small mackmackerel[erel] – not car
rach, smooth

An
t iasg = mullet. Gullit
like a ducks (goile)

An
Callamor = Hawk fish
Herring Hake Manach
Tusk. Siolag. ghobach
as large ling 9 ininches in gob
of this one – blue – not
eaten. not in sand

The breac & the grallag
found in stomach of trosg

MucamarMucamara muca biorabiorach
Cannach. Mucan
biorbiorach leapleaps 20 ffeet high 200 ftfeet
for.forwards aftafter the ling saw
them contcontinually leap frfrom Glass
lightlighthouse to LLoch Bhrollan. leap
aftafter leap. saw anothanother only
at Ceann Bharra. like
the gobaga mora firion
Tamaire – even male
gob large as large as these
2 rows of teeth – no nam
name for this fish. Great
deal of blood dark blood
like a shark than any
any othother fish he saw.

7 rows of teeth when of
maturing. Giobarnach
large ton ton round
meuirean in eye and
eyes in Giobarnal
red in water red tōn
fins instead of ton
2 large wide fin
2 flaps on wings
Gearran cnuaccnuacach = GriasgGriasgaiche.

Eilean O-bharsa lightlighthouse
on this the buryburying ground is
built upon of com.commissioners of
lightslighthouses – wall built over
MacKay's tomb. Bodies
on face whole & 6 ininches
on top of bodies – whole –
These were wheeldwheeled down
to Geo-cho'airGeodh-chobhair. Sear
agach Seargach –
– Sea foam – Co'arCobhar
fresh water foam
Searagach = tough
foam.

GileGille gringrinn foinifoghnaidh siobhsibh
do dh' fior uilfhuil ClanClann AoiAoidh
Bha do shinshinnsirean an Grimsa
se cuir dachdachaidh saor
Am cuimhcuimhne leibh mas
bhioch na sean ansa
GhaGhabh uthu sobhal Bhail Neil
Cha do chumhchuimhnich iad air Neil
Na Ba Nuair a
cheannaich iad an
t sreang. MacAoiMacAoidh
killed by Mac Lathartaich
for paypayment. Killed at Cill
Mhic O Charmaig Knap
adale. Door then made
of sgathach chraobh. Mac
AoMacAoidh going in for a drink
when Maclathartaich was
behind the comhla.
MacAoiMacAoidh asked his man
to bury him air Eilean
O'arsay. Tomba with
inscripinscription Dyke built on
this by comcommissioners – Only 18
years when killed. RelateRelated
to MacAoiMacAoidh na Rainn
from Reay.

The Bac got on the
Bank an iar – Bacach
cearr by some. 80 score
sent to market

Blad-fo-lic goes on edge
shape like leabag. Spot
on each side where the
saviour caught it.

Crag-dhu has pouch on
each side large – Gobag in
Islay Biorach. A
cross is twisttwisted the
Murlach & gobag. Sporan
faolin in Murlach.

The gobag brings forth like a
cat kitten in the boat.

Calamor = Falmair
H. Kaki.

Fish like linling yellow
belly crooked head like
gurnet. There were two of these
got both chub Devil fish

Gibernach bad bolaboladh Two
kinds. Giberneach – bocach
& Ki Gib.Gibearnach sgrathach – Cuttle
fish – Take the ite fly

Siolag with a long gob –
mouth 8 or 9 d circumcircumference.

Fish in the Cuan Barra
flap movgmoving on surface
of sea 11 or 13 ffeet long like
a shell tough as hide – 9
Nathar-thragh = Tarbh
shiolshiolag – pointpointed pencil
like Gearra cnuac
ach like the fish
with the flapping fish
on surface. ("Na bata beaga")

Lad 12 yrsyears old from near
Inverness wldwould lift 2 bags meal
200 lbs Michael Mac-
Illemhicheil his fathfather a
weaver

Beathach big as B.Bradan leathanleathann]
no mionmionach but just a goile.
3 or 4 ftfeet long 2½ broad no
name at PPort na haven. (.Turbot?)

Abhain chuil Davach CoCounty Don.
egal paved with Siolag. The
river comes fr.from Beinn Nar
gad. Johnnie Doran here
6 ininches long place has full
clear bone. St. Peadar's fish.

Sheanartai mmarried dat.daughter to Irish

Calolier put a stop to the

Campbell RevReverend threw down

mhillidh Kintire) Last priest
in Islay. Campbell
of Bailnaby married a dat.daughter of Clan
ranald. She brotbrought a priest here
& when she died she was buried
at behind dyke of B.Baile nabai
near Tobar a' a geo.
Sacred well leaving copper
& fine rags. She too was buribuired
beside the priest – This was
done at thetheir own wish
This Campbell a kin to the
duke of Argyll
Calum cille threw down
the crosses & while he lived
all was right – when he died
the crosses were put up.

Ross GamekeepGamekeeper shot at a
Grey-lag at Loch mna N.North W.West

up frfrom the lake & as he was going
away down came the per
egrine falkon & kiledkilled it
and Mr Ross got near
the end of the loch i ate the
breast. He then tried to get
a shot at the falcon
but the fal.falcon wldwould not ne come
near. TheThen he set a trap
& got it. Bird now with
Capt.Captain John Maccalum

Never saw roe in eel. His
mothmother told him her loinid
got lost & was found aftrafter
a time it was disdiscovered in a well
– it was all alive with
eels. It was made of horse hair
The eyes of the eels distinct. All
wriggling in the most extraoextraordinary
manner & the tails tied togethtogether
in the twisted or plaited rope.
Some say eels in thetheir sleep sea
breed. He often fished them there
but never saw roe in any.
There eels are white. Of old
not eaten in Gearrloch They
are now.

Morgan, Moragan stick
to rocks somewhat like Muc
creaige – Muc creaige numer
ous – Eel caught man at

full of the goll-luachair
reeds (soft) on lakes used

He cut it open & let out the
al. He then put out hook &

No roe in Skate = Sporan

like hen. Nan griollach
in clusters in the skate.

(Bean-she Naoisg? in Irel.Ireland) Tells of death
in a house. If this bird be heard
in the morngmorning death comes
earlier than if later on. When
the wives hear the bird they ask
when the grioglachan is on
the SkyeSky. They have a comh
ara cuan & they tell close
to the correct time of night or
day – cock crow &c

Maorach mor larger than
musgan. Bheil maorach
agaibh a nocnochd Gu dearbh

The Cnogan is the grown Giulla
Fionn. Maorach is toirt
mach a loin. A cat got
drowned at Leacali Harris
by putgputting in his tongue under a
limpet The limpet closed &
drowned. Maorach iallai
is maorach gathgathered at night

Young eagle does not leave

his back Calum Brocair

fly away a day & got it.

p.del:
Mr N Macleod saw
sulair put his bill throthrough
board floating

Sulair went throthrough boat betbetween
Tarauis & Nisibost – He came
down on a fish & ere he reached
the boat came on the spot. The
SulSulaire came & put his bill throthrough the
side of boat. He was fin kept
there to save the boat from
sinking till they reachreached land
The boat was coming from comh-
ail or going home from
comhail.

aliLeacali. Eel caught tao-stoc cattle

p.del:
Glaisvein in Glendail near
Poll tiel = marching with BoigBoirireig
The Campbells had this for keeping
hawks to Macleod of Macleod
This tribe of CampCampbells are called
"Na Seocainean"

Bloody estate BreadBreadalbane estate
An old Campbell of the Seoc
ainean told John Nicolson
that they were of teolachteoghlach a
Bharrabhric wherever that place
is". These are the most numer
ous fine there – more CampCampbells
in DuichDuthaich ic Leoid than Leodaich
themselves. When Macleod
ceased sealgsealgaireachd with hawkhawks this
was no need to keep the Seoc
ainean. They then go it on rent
the rent being 7 yrdsyards clo
breac for hose to Macleod
now rent is £ 100 or so

Crub.Crubain cast shell abtabout end of Aug.August
They go in pairs like birds. One casts
shell & is soft as the faobhag, the other
standstands waitwaiting on the faiche to keep
out intruders & then the other casts
Female casts shell first. good
bait for the Muc creige – best
for bait for her

div.p:
Traille on east side not west
side of S.St Kilda – Skate on N.North WWest
of never saw so the like. Just
cut them off at beulnaavbhat
A big stream could be filled in a
month. Caught two sharks
in S.St Kilda. Got ling cut clean
across shark 7 f[ee]t [supralinear: both] twisted in the
lins dead colour of dog fish
dark in back fair belly. The
LinLing very large there – not so the
other fishes.

Tobar na buadh

A schoolmaster in S.St Kilda
in print.

The BuigireBuagaire comes & leaves on
certain days any year. They fly
in clouds in circles & darken
the air then light on the
ground on top of rocks & cover

The guga is black as raven & larger than
the parent. SSt KildKildans bring 5 or 6
tons of these from Stacali then they
divdivide them on the Leac. Guga is 2 yrsyears
in he is white. The guga does
not all leave all the year.

The SSt KildnKildans value the Fulmar
at 7 d each between oil bird & feather
The SSt KildKildan hshas a goile Sulair
on his belt into which he puts
bill of Ful.Fulmar which pours out his
oil. Then twist neck of FulFulmar throthrough
his Crios ianaich & weaves himself
Bird full of bloinig which SSt K[ildan] uses
takes off feathfeathers & salts bird. Sid e
nis a ghraighraidh Iain am Fulmar
S cha toirinn e eirson
a mhuilt is fhearr san
EilEilean SgithSgitheanach agad
DivDivided the rocks like crofts If
a man loses a Ful.Fulmarthrothrough the
the fault of his neighsneighbour's
his pays 7 d. They sit in parparliament
every morngmorning in the year. You
cant undunderstand a word they say.
Fists up to one another bus.

their ulaiulaidh She goes down to the
strand to traitraigh & takes up a gob
ful Is bigidh e sidsiod Is bigidbigidh
e sidsiod (the sea).
Faninidh e sidsiod said the seang-
an to the gearran.

Mar thug an giodh an car as
an t SionSionnach. I Rug an SionSionnach air a' ghoghiodh
gus a dhuirt e Chan fhadfhaodadh gu bhibhith
thu dol a ghailghabhail do dhindhinnear gun
t altachaltachadh. Dhuin an SionSionnach a shshuilean.
Dh fhalbh an giodh FaoFaodaidh an
altt altachadh bhibhith gle mhath na aite
fhein ach bhi mi mo fhoidfhoighdinn
S mo fhin agam bhbhiodh mo
mo dhidhinnear agam bog blablath mun
bhion ri gagabhail m altaltachadh.

Air lalatha tharsair =
A ghios an t saoghail
Ceiteineach = May Cuddy.

Their trian do nadar ris
an ainm

lg.l: Nuair a thisthig na machar an ru'achain

div.p:
Angus Macinnes AonasAonghas Òg
Arasaig compcomposed Oran an
Fheidh

Co as thainig sibhs a dhuindhuine
Thainig mi a RocabarraiRocabarraidh
Far am bi iad a g ol suthadh saile
Nam faochag sughar leis
an aran eorna.

p.del:
Maoirnean = Mactra helvacia
Madadh Sal = Modiola miod-
iolus. P uidis L. Devon

div.p:
Tern egg soon gets addled. Na
Foraich. Meigausa = Scotlands
Teal – Crannlachan Bheag –
Water Rail = GGearradh Fliuch. W then
CeanCeann uisge. Knot Ruideal
Ghuilbneach –

Live eels go throthrough the Heron & She
turns round & eats it again!

SpeirgSpeireagchaol SpSpeireag ghorm Bheag
Kestrel – P SpSpeireag ruaruadh (Bheag)
An t-Seobhag Bheag Ghorm – most
in st braes in long heather
Kite ClaClamhan gobhlach. R. L.
Buzzard = Clamhan

Martin = Taghan. PcatPolecat Feoc
arlan. Broc – muic ard B.Broc coin

The old wild cat was not so low
in the leg & those in the MuseuMuseum.
bigger in body head like & skin
striped like tiger

Broc min is gollach tinthin & long
in nose.

Seal killed at
Portree blue like hooded seal
AnothAnother Skye maman had a spliucanspliuchan
& he said the seal had been killkilled
on an AfriAfrican river

If Peacock egg is boiled imimmediately it coolcools
& it becomes raw again. It canntcannot
be cooked – Aodach na bainnse
when bird puts on its bloom Crotag-mhor = Curlew

Mhongach-mhear = Di-thosd
Foxglove = Sithein mor

Burdock = Searcan boiled this
curancurran of this as they did croic
nam fiadh = the horns are broken
& sawn & boiled into jelly & candy
sugar like calf head jelly
ErthingEverything these good for – For Con
sumption if not gone far
searcan.

A Cuach at Taigh Gige
T.Taigh G.Gige nam Fir Cachanach)
nan gorm lann) Gearrloch
is family heir loom. Its
calldcalled Beul-an t Seanchais
because no persnperson drank
it but wldwould be seanchaies.
It is vryvery large – holdholding nearly a
stōp. Conch = Conachag
Conachocan.

Madadh Uisg – Abhainn
ChearraiChearraidh Gearrloch rungrunning
into – many there of these.

A MadMadadh Sal drowned a MadMadadh UisUisge
at Coire Torridon at
Ionnar AbhAbhainn a Choire Mhic Nòbaill
in sea.

The Giolla Fionn
is the best one of all
Portan alive ¾ yeryear.

It was in Gearrloch the man
who made the 12 rann fiorfiorionnach
& the 12 rann briagbriagach

lg.l: A falbh is dronagdronnag fhraoich oirr
A dannsdannsa air an lar fhasganta

Se cur is taigh mach nan caorach
A casgradh ris

div.p:
Brig = Cnap, torr as in Brig bhuntabhuntata
Brig-mhoine ach torr chlach
not Brig chlach.
Cu Filear = Sharp scented dog.
Compostello 14 DecDecember 741874 XI – 74 – 76. Scallop shell

Poll Nan Crann –
at Benbecula. People of Grim
nish were cutting sea
ware then some 7 or 8 years
ago say in 1880 or so –
the tide was extraordinarily
low and a well built
stone dyke was in full
view to the amazement
of all at low water.

Gray going down to Newton
ask Norman the BankBanker took
the grave stones at Clachan
for a flock of gray lags & so
began to take notes and sketch
of them – & would take no denial
sketched

Gull swallingswallowing an easganeasgann
chaol dhubh on wing & the
eel going throthrough it three times
each time the Gull caught
it up again ere reaching the
ground

Girl n.named IshIshbel Diarmuid
Skye put her finger in moumouth
of eels head & she was cut
to the bone. Nor.Norman the BankBanker
was present & saw this.

The Bana-bhuisgein bad for the to
Clamhra dughdubh

Toc = sort of inflamation of
the eye of a cow or horse. This
is cut with a needle. This
was Gearradh an tocaidh

Coilleach is Cearc chearr
Da bhoil is leanbuan sean chearr

StrikigStriking the dearnadearnadh to re-
vive a person in a fit
so also in CCailleach an Dudain

lg.l: Far nach cluinn mi guth dhuine
Ach fuaim tuinne s guth geoidh

div.p:
Caolas Odrum between
the isle of Heisgeir and the
isle of Sheilley North Uist
SheallyShealley from Seal (ron) & of
Heisgeir from h-aoi isthmus
and ey – an isle

lg.l: Ged labhradh neach ort gu h-olc
Bi nad thosd s na taisbean fuath
Na bi breithneach s na bi balbh
Na bi mear no marbh 's tu og
Thachair am bard a bhi on thaigh
Cuir suas do bhreid le mile failtfailte

div.p:
Said to have been composed
by Clanranald to his bride

An uncle brought up a nephew
who turned out mean. They
won at a market and the
uncle wished the nephew to give
him a dram before going home
The nephew would not
and the uncle said –

lg.l: An rud bhiodh liomsa bu le Iain
An rud bhiodh le Iain bu bhiodh leis fein

div.p:
The uncle again asked
the nephew and the nephew
again declined. Then the uncle
said Dhoill?

lg.l: Cha b'e comunn an da Ghoill
Ach an rud bhiodh agad fhaotainn uatbhuat
S an rud bhiodh uatbhuat a thoirt dhuit
